Dodik has long insisted that the state of Bosnia is doomed, and that the Republika Srpska should have the right to self-determination. He began spinning this line soon after becoming the entity’s prime minister in 2006, citing the precedent of Montenegro’s independence referendum. He rarely misses a chance to refer to impending or possible independence referenda in Scotland and Catalonia, so it is hardly out of character or surprising that he has now embraced the illegal Crimean referendum, especially since it was engineered by his political idol, Putin. Dodik has openly modelled his development of a ‘vertical of power’ structure on Putin’s operating system in Russia.

But that has begun to backfire. Violent demonstrations in early February by Bosnians angry at the lack of accountability, rampant corruption and general privation visited upon them have put the entire Bosnian political elite on edge. These were particularly widespread in Bosnia’s other entity, the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, whose principal communities are Bosniaks (Bosnian Muslims) and Croats. But these sentiments hold sway state-wide. In Republika Srpska (RS), Dodik’s concentrated power has enabled him to engage in widespread and blatant intimidation of potential popular opponents, visibly manifest in heavier police patrols to deter gatherings. Even as he claims to be defending the RS from conspiracies, whether foreign or domestic, he has also attempted to tarnish the reputations of protesting Serb war veterans who, unlike him, actually fought for the RS.

Dodik reportedly sought credits in Moscow, like those offered to Viktor Yanukovych before he was ousted as Ukraine’s president, so as to be able to avoid relatively mild loan conditions set by the International Monetary Fund and, correspondingly, drive the whole state into further dysfunction. His own economic woes and fears of being toppled in October elections – or even earlier should he not be able to pay the bills – are already driving greater nationalist rhetoric and paranoid behaviour, such as moves to constrain foreign funding of NGOs – just as in Russia. He clearly hopes Russia will support his actions to undermine the Bosnian state.

As the international community’s former high representative in Bosnia, Paddy Ashdown, said on 18 March in Sarajevo: “We must act to close this new salient decisively.” Luckily, a united West has full capability to do just that. What has been lacking is the will to employ it.

As has been the case with European and Western responses to Ukraine, the weakest link has been Germany. In Bosnia, this has been manifest in resistance to a long-overdue European Union and Western policy review on how to use their broad array of tools and instruments more effectively. In contrast to its strong advocacy of financial conditionality within the eurozone, Berlin advocates a soft-touch in Bosnia: pacification through throwing more money at the country’s entrenched kleptocrats. This mollifies existing elites, but forestalls progress toward a functioning system. Ukraine demonstrates that such policies lead to greater corruption and less transparency. Yet Germany continues to insist on it.

The group supervising Bosnia’s compliance with the Dayton peace accords that ended Bosnia’s war in 1995, the Peace Implementation Council (PIC), includes Russia. It does not formally operate by consensus; Russian dissent manifested in footnotes to its periodic communiqués attest to that. Yet for too long Moscow has been able to play the opportunistic spoiler because the West has been divided. As recently as February, German diplomats said a recalibration of the international presence in Bosnia was “impossible” because Russia would not accept it. In the wake of Putin’s dangerous adventurism in Ukraine, such objections are no longer tenable. Berlin must now unequivocally get on-side for a new policy.

Two practical manifestations of this would be a decision by all Western members of the PIC to replace the current high representative – a European, Valentin Inzko – with a high-stature American politician and to restructure his or her office to enable it credibly to defend clear red lines: enforcing Dayton and protecting state institutions and processes. The other would be to beef up the EU’s military deterrent force, EUFOR, so that it could cope with forseeable security challenges, including any moves by Republika Srpska toward independence. Western unity on these moves can still outflank Russian opposition.

Russia’s capacity for mischief in Bosnia – while far less than in Ukraine, the Caucasus, or Transnistria – is still substantial. It comes at no cost to Moscow so long as the West is divided. This has long been evident in PIC meetings and Russia’s blatant favouritism toward Republika Srpska as its client entity. But given Putin’s clearly growing appetite for confrontation and aggrandisement, it is best to preclude it in the Balkans completely. A new pan-Western strategy is necessary in its own right in Bosnia. It is long overdue. Developing and adopting one now will make clear that the Balkans are off-limits for Russian opportunistic adventurism. Doing so will also dramatically reduce the ability of Dodik and the rest of Bosnia’s unaccountable elites to evade the reckoning with their citizens that they so richly deserve.

Kurt Bassuener is a senior associate of the Democratization Policy Council, a think-tank. He lives in Sarajevo.

articles.title: Overstepping the boundaries
content:
Western governments must be prepared to set red lines, and need to be ready to respond if Russia crosses them.

Copy Link
37568
March 26, 2014 9:50 pm CET
By John Wyles
It is grim, but not a fairy story. Europe awakes after a long sleep and, disoriented, fails to recognise its surroundings. There is much that is still familiar: the capital cities are where they have always been, road and rail communications are still working and Angela Merkel is still in charge. Nevertheless, everything is the same but very different. All changed by one single act: Russia’s annexation of Crimea.

To general surprise and shock Vladimir Putin’s land grab has derailed an apparently stable world order whose permanence had been taken for granted in western capitals for more than 20 years. Having believed that 21st-century geopolitics are firmly grounded in collective respect for rules and international law, western governments are now being forced to re-examine their assumptions about Russia’ s approach to foreign policy.

“Russia is acting much more like an adversary than a friend,” says the head of the United States and NATO’s forces in Europe, warning last weekend that the build-up of Russia’s forces on Ukraine’s eastern border is “very, very sizeable and very, very ready”. Norbert Röttgen, chairman of the Bundestag’s foreign affairs committee, was still reeling from shock and spoke for many across Europe when he confessed last week that all his assumptions about the post-Cold War world were in tatters. If someone had asked him a couple of months ago whether Russia was a threat to European stability, “I would have dismissed the idea out of hand.” Now Putin’s Russia “seems to be writing a new chapter in a book we thought we had closed a long time ago”. The Russian president is “openly affirming that he is not willing to play by our rules of international relations”.

Crushingly, the challenge facing western governments begins with having to accept that the Ukraine has lost Crimea and that ipso facto national borders in Europe can be forcibly redrawn. The question now is whether Putin’s ambitions are satisfied. Does he feel that he has gained the respect for Russia he craves or does he need to make a complete meal of Ukrainian sovereignty? Should we, then, expect Russia to foment internal disorder in the east of the country to justify another military intervention in defence of ethnic Russians?

US and NATO leaders are beginning to realise they need a red lines strategy that sets behavioural barriers for Moscow. The first task is to change mindset and recognise that Putin, who once proclaimed the vision of a “common European house” has now burned it down. But what could this mean? After Crimea, is there now a real danger that Putin will scoop up the ethnic Russian enclaves in Moldova’s Transnistria region together with Abkhazia and South Ossettia in Georgia? Inevitably, strategic planning in the NATO alliance must acknowledge that there is a much greater risk of military conflict with Russia than previously thought. If the Kremlin is to be deterred from playing fast and loose with international law in spurious defence of Russian-speaking minorities, it will need to be convinced that the stakes are high.

In the meantime, political isolation, though imperative, will do nothing to contain Russia. Effective economic sanctions are needed to impose real costs on the Russian economy. Those so far adopted by the US and European Union – travel bans and asset freezes for three or four dozen of Putin’s ruling elite – are inflicting pain but will not be decisive. Moscow will retaliate by imposing crippling gas-price rises on Ukraine and implying that Germany and eastern Europe should not take Russian gas supplies for granted. A tit- for-tat game is in prospect with Putin gambling on Europe’s extreme reluctance to levy really costly sanctions. De-escalation – the current objective of sanctions policy – will be as difficult to achieve as it is to define.

This is a defining moment for the EU and, particularly for Germany. The country’s instincts are anything but martial and foreign policy is determinedly driven by economic interest. An internal debate on whether Germany needs to assume more international responsibilities has been meandering inconclusively since last September’s elections. It now has real meaning for Germany and for Europe. If Berlin is fundamentally indulgent and confirms Putin’s view that its real economic interests will not be put on the line, then short-term policies will be weak and ineffective.

Angela Merkel is the only European leader with the power to ensure that the EU’s short-term policy has enough backbone to defend red lines. But she also has to encourage other heads of government to reshape medium-term policies towards Russia. The need to diversify energy supplies is a no-brainer. Europe takes 30% of its gas supplies from Russia and should take much less in future. Technology transfers and arms sales to Moscow must also be reviewed. Most difficult of all, perhaps, is the need to spend more on defence and security. Neither the US nor Europe wants a return to the Cold War in Europe, but if you set red lines you must ultimately be prepared to defend them.

John Wyles is an independent consultant based in Brussels.

articles.title: Showing determination
content:
If we cannot send soldiers, let us at least send observers to Ukraine (and to Moldova).

Copy Link
37707
April 2, 2014 8:50 pm CET
By Grzegorz Gromadzki
The coming weeks and months will see Russia making an effort to destabilise Ukraine at all costs, especially in the east and south of the country. The aim will be to engender chaos and prevent the Ukrainians from conducting presidential elections, scheduled for 25 May.

The Russian foreign ministry has already officially announced that it will not recognise the result of these elections, and President Vladimir Putin will want to show that the current Ukrainian government does not control the country. That is why it must be a priority for the European Union’s aid policy to counter further Russian aggression against Kiev. We must not permit a repeat of the sequence of events in Crimea, when the EU and the West as a whole merely reacted to Russian actions, always a few steps behind. We must take the initiative and hinder Russia’s efforts to destabilise Ukraine, efforts that could lead to armed aggression.

Apart from sanctions, one of the key weapons we have at our disposal is the option of mobilising the greatest possible number of international observers and sending them to Ukraine and especially to the south and the east of the country.

The presence of observers would, clearly, not guarantee that Russia would desist from taking action against Kiev, but it would certainly make life more difficult for them, and would demonstrate the EU’s resolve. This is why the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) observation mission currently in place should be speedily boosted to 500 people.

At the moment the mission has approval from member states for 100 observers and could be augmented by a further 400. If there is delay in sending a further 400 OSCE observers, the EU must revive its idea of sending a separate mission of least 400. The majority of these should be sent to southern and eastern Ukraine.

At the same time, the EU Border Assistance Mission on the Ukrainian border with Moldova should be strengthened by at least 50% (at the moment, it numbers around 100 people from the EU and a further 120 from Moldova and Ukraine). More personnel should be sent to the stretch of the Moldovan-Ukrainian frontier controlled by Transnistria, a breakaway region of Moldova in which Russian soldiers are stationed.

The Kremlin will certainly try to disrupt the presidential election. This is why the OSCE’s separate election-observation mission – created by its Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR) – should be supplemented by a strong mission from the European Parliament and missions organised by EU member states. The ODIHR mission comprises 100 long-term and 900 short-term observers. The international community as a whole should ensure that several thousand international observers are eventually in place.

The Russians might also seek to destabilise the situation in Moldova. Moldova is de facto defenceless, making it easier for groups of masked ‘unknown’ soldiers to act in Chisinau and other Moldovan towns. The EU should therefore also send an observation mission to Moldova, made up of a minimum of 100 people.

If we cannot send soldiers, let us at least send observers. Let us show Putin and his friends that we are determined to protect the right of the Ukrainians to choose their own future. We can be sure that the Russian president will make very determined efforts to hinder the Ukrainian people from that sovereign choice.

Grzegorz Gromadzki is a co-ordinator of an informal group of Polish non-governmental think-tanks dealing with international affairs.

articles.title: A year of crisis and instability on the EU’s doorstep
content:
Major problems in the east and in the south.

Copy Link
37735
April 2, 2014 9:10 pm CET
By Andrew Gardner
In its annual review of the European Union’s neighbourhood, the European Commission described 2013 as “a year of crises”. That was on Thursday (27 March). Hours earlier, on Wednesday, the chief of Egypt’s army, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, had announced he would run for the presidency, a move that augurs another crisis between the military and large parts of Egyptian society.

The Commission had already delayed the report by a week, to accommodate the thoughts of EU leaders at a summit on 20-21 March that was dominated by Ukraine. At present, there does not seem to be a crisis-free week in which to publish a report.

In their dry, neutral tone, the Commission’s country reports display the impact of the multiple crises on the region and on relations with the EU – Syria’s destabilising impact on Jordan and Lebanon, and Russia’s on Ukraine and Armenia, both of which decided at the last minute last year not to sign landmark agreements with the EU. Even where little changes, in the Palestinian territories, a sense of looming crisis emerges. And there is a separate category, of countries where the crises are too big for the EU to have established a work plan for the relationship – Syria and Libya – or where the rulers are too unwilling to agree one, Belarus and Algeria.

There are some bright spots. A sense of genuine dynamism emerges from the report on Moldova. In Georgia, too, the progress is notable. Both, though, are also highly vulnerable to the uncertainty created by Russia: in both cases, Russian troops are already stationed on soil that they consider theirs – Moldova’s Transnistrian region and Georgia’s regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. Tunisia this year passed a relatively liberal constitution. It is, as one national diplomat put it, “the brightest hope of reform for democratic politics” and a country where “we think the EU can be particularly supportive”. But the report itself is more toughly worded than such assessments might suggest – or perhaps the Commission’s candour there is a measure of how diplomatic its wording is in many other reports.

Another potential method to measure countries’ progress is to look at the money (see table). The EU’s guiding principle in its neighbourhood is ‘more for more’ – more progress, more money. That is a reasonable way to understand the low support for Belarus and Azerbaijan. But the principle is affected by need and the EU’s political commitment, hence the large figure for Palestine. In many cases, the EU’s political commitment – the money offered – far outstrips neighbours’ willingness or ability to meet the conditions. The gaps between what is on offer and what is absorbed are striking in many countries. Again, a trio of small states – Moldova, Georgia and Tunisia – emerge at the front of the pack.

The variance in progress – in willingness or ability (or both) – demonstrates the challenge for the European Commission in establishing policies for or relationships with the EU’s neighbours. The notion of the EU as a pole of attraction for its neighbours does not emerge well from the reviews.

An alternative view may soon gain traction. EU officials and diplomats are now used to talking about an ‘arc of instability’ across Africa’s Saharan and Sahel regions; but Greece’s defence minister, Dimitris Avramopoulos, last Thursday applied the term to another region. Addressing the annual conference of the European Defence Agency, Avramopoulos said: “If we take a look at the neighbouring regional reality, we will clearly see an arc of instability stretching from the Ukraine to the northern shores of Africa.”

The next European Commission and the EU’s next foreign policy chief have much to ponder.

THE REPORTS IN BRIEF
The European Union’s neighbourhood policy covers 16 countries. Four countries – Algeria, Belarus, Libya and Syria – have not agreed ‘action plans’ with the EU on steps to be taken to improve the rule of law and democracy and to develop a market economy. Below are developments during 2013 that were highlighted by the European Commission in the annual progress reports on the 12 countries that have agreed action plans. The most beneficial – and demanding – agreements that the EU currently offers to countries in the neighbourhood are political agreements of association, which include a new generation of trade provisions called ‘deep and comprehensive free-trade agreements’ (DCFTAs).

UKRAINE
Political relationship: Prepared but did not sign association agreement; late in the year a political crisis erupted, leading to mass street protests and (this year) the departure of President Viktor Yanukovych and a Russian invasion. Trade and business relationship: Prepared but did not sign DCFTA; initialled aviation agreement; failed to resolve trade cases (car-recycling fees, local content of renewable energy equipment); needs to do more to comply with Energy Community Treaty.

Visas and migration: Addressed “some” recommendations in visa liberalisation action plan with EU, including adoption of legislation.

Other successes: “Positive developments” with reform of judiciary and self-governance; “some progress” on cases of selective use of justice; “good progress” against human trafficking; “improvement” in anti-corruption legislation.

Other weaknesses: “No work” on improving laws on presidential and local elections; corruption; “backsliding” on public procurement and budget transparency; media freedom worsened during Euromaidan protests. Need for: Constitutional reform; “reliable and uniform” electoral system; reform of prosecutor-general’s office, judiciary, police; anti-corruption efforts in “all areas of public life”; compliance with international refugee and human-rights law. Need to improve the business climate and prepare for IMF support.

MOLDOVA
Political relationship: Political crisis in early 2013, but managed to initial association agreement; “significant efforts” to implement agreement on civil protection, participate in EU agencies and programmes, and co-operate with EU common security and defence policy.

Trade and business relationship: Initialled DCFTA; “significant efforts” to implement agreements on aviation and agriculture.

Visas and migration: Completed implementation of visa liberalisation action plan.

Other successes: Addressed “many” key recommendations, including reform of judiciary, law enforcement, regulations and business sectors; restructured anti-corruption framework; progressed with human-rights action plan and plan for Roma minority; and continued to de-politicise and professionalise public administration.

Other weaknesses: Need to revise the constitution, to implement DCFTA and association agreement and to deepen reform of public administration. Need to make greater efforts to curb corruption, to reform justice and law enforcement, to consolidate systems related to human rights and fundamental freedoms, to reform public broadcaster and education system. Business climate needs improving, including continued privatisation. “Little development” in talks with breakaway region of Transnistria.

TUNISIA
Political relationship: Developed at “moderate pace” (‘national dialogue’ accelerated late in the year); new ENP action plan yet to be finalised.

Trade and business relationship: Signed pan-Euro- Mediterranean rules of origin; continued talks on aviation agreement; preparations for DCFTA talks not yet completed.

Visas and migration: Established dialogue on migration, mobility and security.

Other successes: Progress on consolidation of democracy (including on a new constitution, legal and financial reforms, judiciary, corruption, torture); progress on electoral procedures; “significant progress” on public finances.

Other weaknesses: “No progress” on military courts; “significant barriers” to freedom of assembly and expression; “excessive use of force” against demonstrators; journalists and activists jailed; “significant concern” about violence against women. Concerns also include: treatment of migrants and asylum-seekers; reform of judiciary and security and law-enforcement sectors; business climate; uneven economic development; energy subsidies; banking sector; public-finances funding.

MOROCCO
Political relationship: “Particularly dynamic” year.

Trade and business relationship: Began talks on a DCFTA; “good progress” on harmonisation of rules on industrial goods.

Visas and migration: Established a ‘mobility partnership’.

Other successes: “Most” recommendations acted on, including some progress on discrimination, corruption, justice reform; worked on anti-corruption strategy; strengthened laws on money-laundering and terrorist financing.

Other weaknesses: “Limited” implementation of “ambitious” political reforms; “disproportionate” force used against demonstrators; reform of media law not completed; use of military courts; implementation of migration and policy plans; social-security systems; corruption; subsidies system.

EGYPT
Political relationship: “Politically a very challenging year”; “no particular progress” with EU action plan.

Trade and business relationship: Signed pan-Euro- Mediterranean preferential rules of origin; “limited progress” on harmonisation of technical rules on industrial products; “little interest” in starting talks on a DCFTA.

Visas and migration: Not highlighted.

Other successes: “Some signs of [economic] stabilisation.

Other weaknesses: Constitution; conditions for civil society; freedom of assembly and press “deteriorated”; women’s rights; asylum rules; torture camps; judiciary, including military courts; weak social-safety net.

LEBANON
Political relationship: Despite political, security and refugee crises, still committed to “strong” engagement with EU. Lebanon started start implementing second ENP Action Plan; EU “substantially” increased “extent and intensity” of support.

Trade and business relationship: “Limited progress” on harmonisation of rules on industrial goods; need for WTO accession and ratification of Euro-Mediterranean preferential rules of origin.

Visas and migration: Not mentioned.

Other successes: “Commendably” open to refugees; “took up several” EU recommendations; drafted laws on public procurement, corruption, and migration; human rights and freedoms “generally well-respected”.

Other weaknesses: Social and political systems under strain from Syrian refugees; need for electoral and judicial reform; public finance management; “urgent” energy-sector problems; some censorship.

AZERBAIJAN
Political relationship: Negotiations continuing on association agreement and on ‘strategic modernisation partnership’.

Trade and business relationship: Azerbaijan is selected route for gas pipeline to Europe; “no significant progress” toward World Trade Organization accession (a pre-condition for DCFTA talks).

Visas and migration: Signed visa-facilitation agreement and mobility partnership in 2013.

Other successes: Pipeline “should reinforce” Europe’s energy security; some anti-corruption measures.

Other weaknesses: “Very little progress” on democratic governance and human rights; “serious concerns” about elections; failure to honour commitments to Council of Europe; stalemate over Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, including refusal to give access to EU officials.

JORDAN
Political relationship: Increased EU aid because of the ‘severe’ effects of Syrian crisis.

Trade and business relationship: Ratified pan-Euro- Mediterranean preferential rules of origin. Progress in three areas on harmonising rules on industrial goods.

Visas and migration: Talks began on a establishing a ‘mobility partnership’.

Other successes: “Acted upon a number of key recommendations”, including anti-corruption strategy.

Other weaknesses: Arrests of opponents; websites blocked; restrictive media laws; corruption a “serious concern”; “no progress” on independence of the judiciary. Need to repeal or amend constitutional amendments from 2011, to integrate women, to sign IMF programme, to improve business climate and to modernise controls of public finance.

ARMENIA
Political relationship: Negotiations completed for an association agreement, but deal not initialled.

Trade and business relationship: Negotiations on DCFTA completed, but not initialled.

Visas and migration: Visa facilitation and readmission agreements entered into force on 1 January 2014.

Other successes: Addressed “some” of the EU’s key recommendations; law on equal rights; preparation for electoral, rights and anti-corruption reform; “generally well-administered” elections; freedoms of association and assembly “generally respected”.

Other weaknesses: “Mistrust” of judiciary, “lack of convincing results” on corruption, “allegations of use of torture”, increased violence against activists, stalemate over Nagorno-Karabakh conflict.

ISRAEL
Political relationship: EU offers ‘special privileged partnership’ if peace deal is struck; agreement on Israel’s participation in EU’s Horizon 2020 research programme.

Trade and business relationship: Agreement on harmonisation of technical rules for industrial goods enters force. Signed aviation agreement; signed pan-European rules of origin. Some sanitary and food issues, and technical barriers to trade remain.

Visas and migration: No discussions.

Other successes: Addressed “some” recommendations, including “limited progress” on decreasing use of administrative detention of Palestinians.

Other weaknesses: Increased settlement activity and demolitions; “heavy restrictions” on Gaza Strip; respect for international law and human rights in occupied territories; treatment of irregular migrants and asylum-seekers; internal procedures for stateless people; minority rights; intellectual property rights; carbon emissions; independence of the Equal Employment Opportunities Commission.

PALESTINE
Political relationship: “Major step forward” in form of a new ENP action plan; EU continues rule-of-law mission; EU ready to reactivate Rafah border mission; EU offers ‘special privileged partnership’ if peace deal is struck.

Trade and business relationship: Signed pan-Euro- Mediterranean preferential rules of origin; comprehensive National Export Strategy is “a major achievement”; Israeli restrictions “severely” limit effectiveness of EU measures to stimulate the private sector.

Visas and migration: Not mentioned.

Other successes: “Increasing” investigations into corruption.

Other weaknesses: Israeli occupation “biggest obstacle to reforms, especially to the [Palestinian Authority’s] financial sustainability”; PA’s authority “not effective in the Gaza Strip”; Legislative Council “paralysed”; deteriorating freedom of expression in Gaza; “most” key recommendations not addressed; transparency and accountability of justice and security sectors; human-rights standards; integration of women; public-sector reform; water and waste-water management system.

GEORGIA
Political relationship: Initialled association agreement; “intensive” political dialogue with EU; “important” progress on security co-operation.

Trade and business relationship: Initialled association agreement. Visas and migration: “Significant progress” in implementing visa facilitation and readmission agreements.

Other successes: Acted “on most of the [EU’s] key recommendations”; elections “in line with international standards”.

Other weaknesses: More action needed on separation of powers, judicial and policing reforms, media pluralism, “zero tolerance” on hate speech, preparations to implement DCFTA."

articles.title: Pro-EU parties ahead in Moldova
content:
Pro-Russian party wins in late surge, but the balance of seats favours pro-European parties.

Copy Link
High turnout expected in pivotal Moldovan vote
December 1, 2014 10:58 pm CET
By Andrew Gardner
Pro-European parties in Moldova have emerged with a narrow parliamentary majority from national elections that international observers said were characterised by a battle over the country’s geopolitics.

With 94% of votes counted, the strongest party in the parliament is the Socialist Party (PSRM), whose leadership Russia has been courting. It secured 21.2% of the votes cast in the election yesterday (30 November). The third-largest group in parliament, the Communist Party of Vladimir Voronin (PCRM), has also adopted policies seen in Moldova as favouring Russia. Its share of the vote is 17.9%.

However, they may lose out in the post-election coalition-forming to three pro-European parties that operated together in government from 2009 until March 2013. The combined tally of the three parties – the Liberal Democrats (PLDM), with 19.6%, the Democrats (PD) with 15.8%, and the Liberals (PL) with 9.5% – is 44.9%. The PSRM and PCRM have 40.1%. A third left-wing party, the Communist Reformist Party, gained 5.0% of the vote, but fell short of the 6% needed to gain seats in parliament.

Current calculations give the potential pro-European alliance 56 seats in the 101-member parliament, against 45 for the Socialists and Communists.

Past tensions between the Liberal Democrats, Democrats and Liberals could, however, make the formation of a pro-EU government uncertain. The Liberals left the government last year.

Vlad Filat, the Liberal Democrats’ leader, said: “Moldova must remain an independent state and not a vassal state”, referring to Russia.

Igor Dodon, the Socialists’ leader, said that his party would make “the European integrationists shake with fear”. Both the Socialists and Communists have been advocating closer economic integration with Russia, which has invited Moldova to join the Russia-dominated Eurasian Economic Union (EEU), a customs union. Dodon said today that he would call a motion in parliament in favour of a referendum on joining the EEU.

The election process

In the closing days of the election campaign, which saw the governing parties stage a powerful comeback after a year-long slump, the central election commission banned a pro-Russian party, Patria (Homeland), on the grounds that it had received illegal funding from abroad.

Election monitors from the Organization for Co-operation and Security in Europe (OSCE), a 57-country group whose members include Russia, said that voters had a wide choice, parties’ access to the media was “unimpeded”, the elections were “generally well administered”, and the legal framework was “adequate”. It also said that the campaign had been “largely substantive” and that language and identity issues “did not feature predominately in the campaign”.

However, the OSCE said that Patria’s de-registration “raised questions about the timing and circumstances”, while the head of the OSCE’s team, Emin Önen, said that “the late removal of a highly visible party from the ballot cast a shadow over the final days”.

Önen also stated that “geopolitical aspirations” were “at the heart of the campaign”, an oblique reference to Moldova’s emergence as another point of friction between the EU and Russia.

Moldova shares a border with Ukraine, which over the past nine months has lost control of parts of two eastern regions and seen another – Crimea – annexed by Russia since pro-EU and anti-government protests led to the emergence of a pro-EU administration in Kiev. Like Ukraine, Moldova has this year taken a major step in the direction of the EU by signing a political and trade deal – an association agreement – with the EU that would, if implemented by Moldova, lead to far-reaching reform of its economy and governance.

“The EU now looks forward to the swift formation of an inclusive and accountable government, as well as a constructive opposition,” the EU’s foreign policy chief, Federica Mogherini, and the European commissioner for the EU’s neighbourhood, Johannes Hahn, said in a joint statement. They said that they EU would support Moldova “on its path towards more transparency, rule of law and a stronger market economy”.

Dmitry Rogozin, one of Russia’s deputy prime ministers, accused the Moldovan authorities of disenfranchising the many Moldovans who live in Russia.

According to Sputnik, a news outlet funded by the Russian government, Rogozin claimed that there are 700,000 Moldovans in Russia and argued that inclusion of their votes and those of Patria supporters would have rendered the real proportion of pro-European voters “insignificant”.

Rogozin, who is subject to sanctions by the EU and the United States for his role in Russia’s annexation of Crimea in March, also reportedly said that the Moldovan government should “think carefully about the country’s European integration”.

The OSCE has not commented specifically on the conduct of the elections abroad. However, it noted “the lack of transparency with regard to the criteria for determining the number and location of polling stations abroad” and said that this had “contributed to the perceptions of a number of stakeholders” that the government was trying to discourage voting in Russia. “The number and locations of polling stations abroad was widely discussed during the campaign,” it said.

In all, 95 polling stations were opened in 31 countries, five of them in Russia. Figures on the number of Moldovans living abroad vary from 300,000 – from the statistics office – to about 700,000, from the central bank. A minority of diaspora Moldovans live in Russia.

The central election commission put the number of eligible voters at 3.2 million, up from 2.7 million in the 2010 parliamentary elections. According to the OSCE, the election commission attributed this increase of roughly 500,000 to population growth and the inclusion of voters living abroad and voters in Transnistria. Voting was impossible in Transnistria, which broke away from Moldova in 1992. It is unclear how many of the estimated 500,000 Transnistrians were considered eligible to vote by the election commission.

The election campaign

The election campaign saw pro-EU parties come from behind and produce a major change in the balance of power on the left, with the Socialists gaining as much as 18 percentage points over the campaign. Its surge was helped by the roughly 10% of Moldovans who had told pollsters that they would support Patria prior to the party’s de-registration. The Communists had begun the campaign with a sizeable advantage over all other parties. Their final tally was a little over half of their best rating during the campaign.

Kamil Całus of the Warsaw-based Centre for Eastern Studies (OSW), says that during the campaign Russia switched its support away from the Communists in favour of Patria and the Socialists. The Socialists had benefited from strong support on Russian media, which are widely viewed and listened to in Moldova, and by a visit by Dogon to Moscow on 4 November to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin.

During the campaign, Russia increased its economic pressure on Moldova, banning all imports of live animals and meat products. It had already barred imports of Moldovan wine, fruit and vegetables, and some meat products. However, it also chose to extend a gas-supply agreement with Moldova by a year, rather than act on an earlier threat to turn the taps off.

Moldova’s relationship with the EU has deepened significantly over the past year. Moldova is already benefiting from trade privileges contained in the association agreement between Moldova and the EU, which was signed on 27 June and which is now being ratified by the EU’s member states. On 28 April, the EU also granted Moldovans with biometric passports the right to travel to the EU without visas for up to three months. The EU has also said it is willing to provide Moldova with between €335 million and €410m between 2014 and 2017 to develop its agricultural sector, reform public administration, and modernise its policies and border management.

articles.title: Moldova election: Pro-EU parties edge pro-Russian rivals
content: This video can not be played
Ben Bland reports on results from Moldova's parliamentary elections
Latest results from Moldova's parliamentary elections show that pro-EU parties have a narrow lead over those backing closer ties with Russia.
With most of the votes counted, the three pro-Western parties have about 44%. The opposition has 39%.
No party appears to be able to form a government, and tough post-election bargaining is predicted.
The elections have taken on a wider significance in the shadow of the conflict in neighbouring Ukraine.
Moldova and Ukraine have signed far-reaching partnership agreements with the EU, bitterly opposed by Russia.
On the eve of the vote, one pro-Russian party was banned from Sunday's poll - a move criticised by Russia.
Residents of the Russian-backed breakaway region of Trans-Dniester did not take part in the election.
Analysis by Nick Thorpe, BBC Central Europe correspondent

The three pro-EU parties will have a big enough majority to form a government. But those aspirations have been dented by the strong showing of the Socialist Party, which wants Moldova to join Russian President Vladimir Putin's planned Eurasian Union instead.
As the largest single party in the new parliament, Socialist leader Igor Dodon promised that his party in opposition would make the "European integrationists shake with fear".

Tough bargaining lies ahead. One reason for the fall in support for the pro-European parties - from 52% at the 2010 elections, to 44.6% per cent now - was their history of infighting. Another reason was their perceived corruption.
The election also showed a change in popularity for the three main pro-Russian parties. The younger and more outspoken Socialists overtook the Communists.

According to latest results, the three pro-European parties are set to have 57-58 seats in Moldova's 101-seat parliament, while the two pro-Russian opposition parties are expected to hold 43-44 seats, reports say.

The pro-Russian Socialist Party came first with 21% of the vote. The Communist Party was in third with almost 18%. The party is a Soviet-era survivor that still uses the hammer and sickle as its symbol, although it is not seen as fundamentally opposed to EU integration.

The pro-EU Liberal Democrats were in second place with 19%. The party wants Moldova to achieve EU candidate status by 2017 and full membership by 2020. Two other pro-Europe parties - the Democrats and the Liberals - were on  16% and 9% respectively.
There have been reports that the pro-EU parties may now try to form a "grand coalition" with the communists to keep the country on the European track.
Between East and West - Russian dolls can be bought in Chisinau markets

Ukraine has been in crisis since last November, when the former leadership made a last-minute U-turn, refusing to sign a landmark association and free trade deal with the EU - under huge pressure from Russia.

This triggered mass protests in Ukraine that ousted President Viktor Yanukovych, and Kiev later signed the EU deal. But the protests, in turn, led to Russia annexing southern Crimea peninsula in March and throwing support behind separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine.

Ahead of the Moldova vote, analysts said poll ratings of the Socialists, who want Moldova to turn its back on the EU and join a Russia-dominated economic bloc, had been boosted by their populist campaigning, including concerts by Russian pop stars.
Moldova remains one of the poorest countries in Europe
The pro-Moscow parties had been expected to pick up additional votes after the decision to ban the pro-Russian Fatherland party, on the grounds that it had illegally received foreign funding.
Fatherland, whose leader fled to Russia, denies the claim.
Turnout was just under 56%, the central electoral commission said, out of a total of 2.7 million eligible voters.
Parties need to get at least 6% of the vote to gain seats in parliament.
The opposition was also hoping to capitalise on the growing economic problems under the pro-Western government in Moldova - one of Europe's poorest countries.
The situation worsened after a Russian ban on imports of Moldovan agricultural products - including wine, meat, fruit and vegetables.

articles.title: The plight of Moldova's orphanage children
content: Reliance on the state partially explains the number of children brought up in institutions
More than 7,000 children have been placed in state-run institutions in Europe's poorest country, Moldova, and only 2% are orphans.
While the horror stories of the orphanages of 1990s Romania were widely publicised, the conditions facing children in neighbouring Moldova are not well known.

Widespread poverty and a lack of basic social services are blamed for a situation which aid groups argue violates a child's right to a family, as enshrined in theUN Convention on the Rights of the Child,external.
In the capital, Chisinau, the institutions are surprisingly well maintained.
From the outside, the one I was able to visit looked like a school, with plants and a play area, while inside there were pictures on the walls and toys on display.
Yet the first thing you notice is how quiet it is: dozens of young children live in the institution, but you do not hear any noise.
The toys are not being played with; instead children are lying in cots. In one room is a group of about a dozen toddlers.
Some parents leave Moldova to seek work, and leave their children behind
They believe their children will be better off under the care of the state
These youngsters rarely go outside, says Lavinia (not her real name), who works with Hope and Homes for Children, a charity that tries to return children to their families.
Instead, the children spend almost all of their time in just two rooms.
In the corner, a disabled child is left lying in vomit.
No pictures indoors are allowed.
The manager says there are not enough staff to take the children outside, although there appear to be more staff than children.
Lavinia is clearly frustrated by the attitude, but there is little she can do, even though she is working with local authorities on reforming childcare services.
"What we need is to inform and educate families," she says.
"If we can develop family alternatives, this would prevent more children having to live like this."
In another room, 10 newborns lie alone in cots. The institution's manager does not know their sexes.
The standards are shocking for Sarah Butterworth, a UK mental-health specialist on children in care who is visiting at the same time.
"[Knowing] how the brain develops in the first few months of life means I can only imagine the damage that is happening before our eyes," she says.
But experts say institutions are often the worst way to raise children
In one institution, the children simply did not go outside
Although basic needs appear to have been met, these do not look like valued children.
Most of them are not even orphans; they have families but have been abandoned because of poverty and an outdated social reliance on state care.
Moldova's Soviet legacy still remains, and reliance on the state care is embedded in people's attitudes and the law, according to Dr Delia Pop of Hope and Homes for Children.
"For many, institutional care has become the only option," she says. "The irony is that it gets called 'childcare', even though this is one of the most damaging systems for children."
The authorities accept changes are needed but say one of the biggest obstacles is the weakness of the Moldovan economy.
"We want to reform institutions for babies and young children," says Svetlana Chifa, head of the Child Protection Department in Chisinau.
Unemployment in Moldova is high and young adults often head abroad to find work, leaving their children behind to the state.
They believe what they are doing is for the best.
There is also the stigma of disability. A three-year-old I visited, who has been helped into a foster family, was abandoned simply because he was born without an arm.
The situation is even harder  in the breakaway eastern region of Trans-Dniester, which is technically part of Moldova but sees itself as a separate country.
"Trans-Dniester has an attitude for independence, and has strong connections with former Soviet countries," says Dr Pop.
This gives aid workers additional challenges in encouraging co-operation to get children out of institutions and back with their families.
Visiting the region is like going back in time.
The region of Trans-Dniester lies on the Ukrainian border, and considers itself independent

Placing children in such institutions is simply firefighting an ever-expanding, complex social problem rather than offering a long-term solution for the many children within their walls, says children-in-care specialist Sarah Butterworth.
Even when compared with children living in the most deprived of households, children in care are more likely to grow up as dysfunctional adults.
"Years of research have shown the importance of family-based care and attachment, which children in institutions just aren't offered," she says.
Developmental needs, attachment, love and consistency are overlooked.

The authorities in Moldova acknowledge solving this problem is about changing ingrained attitudes and will not happen overnight, partly because many who work in such institutions have a vested interest in them remaining open.
"People are cautious about changes," says Svetlana Chifa.
"The institutions are their livelihoods and people could lose their jobs when they close."
